title: 109_hr3672
content: The Act titled "TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005" allows for the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 authorizes the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, extending activities through December 31, 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 allows for the appropriation of necessary funds for grants and payments until the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. Amendments include extending activities through December 31, 2005, and adjusting dates in the Social Security Act. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 allows for the appropriation of funds for grants and payments until the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. Amendments include extending activities through December 31, 2005, and adjusting dates in the Social Security Act. Funds are appropriated for grants and payments until the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, with necessary sums authorized for fiscal year 2005. SEC. 3. Reimbursement of states for TANF benefits provided to assist families affected by Hurricane Katrina from other states. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until August 31, 2006, a State can qualify as a needy State under section 403(b) of the Social Security Act if they have provided short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits to families displaced by Hurricane Katrina from another State declared a major disaster area. The State can qualify as a needy State under the Social Security Act by providing short-term cash benefits to families displaced by Hurricane Katrina from another State declared a major disaster area. The total amount paid to a needy State shall not exceed the cash benefits provided to the families, with no state match required. The State can qualify as a needy State under the Social Security Act by providing short-term cash benefits to families displaced by Hurricane Katrina from another State declared a major disaster area. No State Match Required for payments made to a State by reason of this section. SEC. 4. Availability of additional TANF funds for hurricane-damaged states. Certain States like Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act until the end of fiscal year 2006. The loans made to these states cannot exceed 20 percent of the State family assistance grant for that year. Additionally, these states will not face penalties for failing to repay the loans. Under the Social Security Act, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are exempt from penalties for not repaying loans or making interest payments after the enactment of the Act until October 1, 2007. SEC. 5 allows States or tribes to use unspent TANF funds to support needy families affected by Hurricane Katrina without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 6 states that work requirements and time limits under the TANF program are not triggered by families receiving temporary TANF benefits due to the hurricane. SEC. 6 states that work requirements and time limits under the TANF program are not triggered by families receiving temporary TANF benefits due to Hurricane Katrina. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states of Louisiana, Mississippi, or Alabama for non-compliance with certain provisions of the Social Security Act due to Hurricane Katrina or state's efforts to assist victims. SEC. 8 designates each amount in the Act (excluding section 2) as an emergency requirement under section 402 of H. Con. Res. 95 (109th Congress).
